title: ENTREPRENEURSHIP
quote: He who is not courageous enough to take risks will accomplish nothing in life.
intro: The high unemployment rate and the precariousness of salaried employment are pushing, and will continue to push more and more young Cameroonian (graduates or not) to start their own businesses in future.
intro2: Here some key information on what to know and do before starting a business..

content1.title: Things to know and do before starting a business
content1.intro: More than 90% of start-ups fail within the first two years of existence. If you do not want to be included in these statistics in the future, take the time and care before starting your business to:
content1.item1: Assess your entrepreneurial potential: through a skills assessment (knowledge, know-how, soft skills, motivation etc.);
content1.item3: Learn about your market: size, turnover, competitors, regulations, etc.;
content1.item4: Develop a Business plan outlining your business model;
content1.item5: Possess or have developed l the essential qualities of an entrepreneur (see below); a mentor or coach can help you do this!
content1.item6: Acquire basic notions of management and accounting;
content1.item7: Get informed about the legislative and regulatory framework relating to the creation and support of SMEs;
content1.item8: Build up an investment capital and be informed about where you can get funding for your business;
content1.item9: Carefully plan the implementation of your action plan with the objectives to be achieved (weekly, monthly...)
content1.item10: Prepare a backup plan in case the project fails.
content1.maniere: More concretely, you will need to:
content1.maniere1: have or develop an original idea (solving a problem or meeting a need) as well as a well thought-out “business model”;
content1.maniere2: calculate all your costs carefully, taking into account unforeseen circumstances;
content1.conclusion: If your result is largely profitable, there is a good chance that your business is profitable and sustainable.
content1.majorite: Last but not least, you should know that most of the successful entrepreneurs:
content1.majorite1: do not mention the quest for gain (becoming rich) as the main driving force behind their actions, but the passion for what they do and the desire to make the world a better place.
content1.majorite2: The billionaire Dietrich Mateschitz, Austria number one fortune and cofounder of the energy drink Red Bull, said in one of his rare interviews that money always came last after the quest for freedom, independence and passion for his projects.
content1.majorite3: did not try to anticipate everything or wait for everything to be ready;
content1.majorite4: they took action as soon as possible and progressed by learning from their mistakes.

content2.title: CORE QUALITIES OF AN ENTREPRENEUR
content2.intro: In order to avoid being overwhelmed by the euphoria of success, the pressure, the stress and the risk of failure inherent in any entrepreneurial project, the young graduate who wants to succeed must, in addition to his competences, develop the following fundamental skills and qualities possessed by the majority of successful entrepreneurs:

item1.title: Be ambitious and bold
item1.text: To be an entrepreneur is to be ambitious, bold and willing to take risks;

item2.title: High level of self-confidence
item2.text: Be confident in your ability to complete your project;

item3.title: Determination and patience
item3.text: Success does not happen overnight and sometimes takes a long time;

item4.title: Leadership
item4.text: Thinking of others and acting for the common good rather than focusing on one's own interests (the basis of all positive impact leadership!)

item5.title: Adaptability and flexibility
item5.text: Ability to question and change course or working methods if necessary;

item7.title: Ability to work in team
item7.text: To ensure cohesion among its employees;

item8.title: Be rigorous and organised
item8.text: To plan, prioritise and implement actions effectively;

item9.title: Be optimistic
item9.text: To believe in the success of the project and remain positive in the face of adversity and setbacks;

item10.title: Be honest and fair
item10.text: Whether with your employees or with your customers and partners, always be honest and fair; don't cheat anyone, your reputation will follow you everywhere. Remember the old saying: “Ill-gotten gains seldom prosper”.

content3.title: Benefits and disadvantages of being an entrepreneur
content3.intro: Just like any other project, Entrepreneurship has its own drawbacks. Here are a few:

item1.title: Independence and freedom:
item1.text: you are your own boss, free in your choices and decisions and implement your own ideas. You organise your own schedule.

item2.title: Satisfaction :
item2.text: working in a field you love, providing a solution to a client's need, becoming a source of inspiration through your success, etc. gives great satisfaction and pride.

item3.title: Financial autonomy:
item3.text: if you are successful, your income will be substantial and will guarantee you financial autonomy.

item4.title: Choice of your employees:
item4.text: you set up and recruit your own team according to your preferences

item1.title: you will not have fixed working hours and your private life may suffer, hence the importance of good organisation and self-discipline.

item2.title: Financial insecurity:
item2.text: if your business takes a long time to become profitable, you will have a low and irregular income; if you go bankrupt, you will lose the capital invested.

item3.title: Uncertainties :
item3.text: related to the search for financing, the loyalty of customers or suppliers, the success or failure of the project.

item4.title: High pressure and stressful situations are guaranteed:
item4.text: due to the competition; the numerous charges: rent, salaries; your responsibilities (finding partners/clients, coordinating the team, accounting, etc.); and even jealousy and envy from the people around you if you are successful.

content4.title: Barriers to formal entrepreneurship
content4.p1: he majority of young people or graduates who embark on entrepreneurship work in the informal sector, mainly in trade, handicrafts, agropastoral activities and services. Taxation, corruption and administrative red tape (particularly for obtaining the trade register, the taxpayer's card and affiliation to the NSIF) are among the obstacles most cited by these entrepreneurs to justify their choice of the informal sector (1).
content4.p2: The important cost of drawing up the aforementioned administrative documents relating to the formality also represents a major obstacle to the formalisation of the company: CFAF 41,500 on average for an establishment (Sole Proprietorship Company, SPC) to more than CFAF 54,625 for a Limited Liability Company (LLC) in a CFCE in addition to other taxes.
content4.p3: Last but not least, the choice of the informal sector is also motivated by the non-payment of taxes. That said, the informal sector also has its share of disadvantages, which are more or less restrictive depending on the activity.
content4.inconvenient: DISADVANTAGES OF WORKING IN THE INFORMAL SECTOR
content4.item1: Exclusion from almost all state programmes to help and support entrepreneurship (training, coaching, tax benefits, guaranteed credit, etc.);
content4.item5: Inability to do business with foreign partners; etc.

content5.title: Starting your business after or without a prior work experience?
content5.p1: Although there are several cases of young graduates who have successfully completed their project immediately after graduation, the fact remains that a first professional experience is in many respects a major asset when starting a business.
content5.p2: Benefits of a first work experience
content5.p3: A first work experience allows you to:

item4.title: Benefit from
item4.text: training opportunities (accounting, tax, sales, etc.) paid for by the employer;

item5.title: Learn about an activity sector:
item5.text: competitors and suppliers, distribution networks, etc.;

item7.title: Bild up savings
item7.text: which could be used to finance your business;

item6.title: Build up a network of contacts

item8.title: Detect an unmet need
item8.text: in your field or a business opportunity; etc.

content5.conclu: These various assets will undoubtedly be useful for the maturation and implementation of your project. We therefore recommend that, in case you have the opportunity, you do not hesitate to acquire professional experience before starting your project (including internships or volunteering during and after your studies).
content5.conclu2: But if you decide to start your own business without work experience, we advise you to develop during your studies, beside your business idea, the main qualities to face the challenges and difficulties you will encounter as an entrepreneur.

content7.title: General knowledge
content7.p1: Importance of general knowledge and reading.
content7.p2: General knowledge is an essential part of a student's life, and later on in professional life. Indeed, in one hand it allows to discover the level of curiosity of the student and in the other to evaluate his or her knowledge outside of his or her field of training. Nowadays, most training providers often subject applicants to a general knowledge test in form of multiple-choice questions or essay. General knowledge is defined as the totality of knowledge in different fields possessed by an individual; and, on the other hand, the ability to use it to express reasoned opinions, to be more open-minded. This knowledge often applies to a limited population in a specific region and at a specific time.
content7.p4: Intellectual curiosity and a strong desire to expand one's knowledge are the main driving forces behind the development of general knowledge in the individual.
content7.p5: One of the most effective ways of developing general knowledge is to read every day, as this amplifies the capacity to memorise. Reading can be done either in the traditional way in a library with different books, or through the panoply of media available: online or paper press, specialised or generalist magazines online or on paper.Besides reading, you can also enrich your knowledge by taking part in lectures on campus or in cultural centres, book signings, visiting museums, etc. and even learning to play a musical instrument.

content8.title: Structures et programmes d’accompagnement à l’entrepreneuriat
content8.intro: Bien qu’il existe plusieurs cas de (jeunes) diplômés ayant mené à bien leur projet immédiatement à la sortie des bancs, il n’en demeure pas moins qu’<b>une première expérience professionnelle présente à bien des égards un atout majeur lorsqu’on se lance dans l’entrepreneuriat.
